So how often do character backstories end up actually driving stuff in your campaigns? I know everyone has different opinions on how much backstory a character should bring into a game, but I've found more often than not even the most detailed character backstories end up being fluff for the story a GM prepared beforehand.

Is it actually common for campaigns to have like, characters go hunt down their father's killer and resolve family drama or is that just a vestige of Actual Play performance shit?

Never. I don't like backstories, I prefer going off of what happens during play instead.
It's always kind of dull when one of the characters has some important moment with Rando Calrissian who only he knows because he wrote about him in his backstory, but he's never actually interacted with him ingame, and he's the only one who can really get involved because Rando only knows him and doesn't have much of a reason to interact with anyone else.
If the dynamic is instead that the party is hired by the baron to do some job, then everyone knows the baron equally well, and they're kind of on equal footing with each other in every interaction with the baron from thereon out. I like when PCs have some sort of "background" instead, so this guy was a carpenter, this guy was a soldier, this lady was a wizard's apprentice, this guy stole onions and got exiled, because it doesn't come with the "baggage" of a backstory, but it still informs a little bit about the character's former life, and gives them a few "unlisted skills", like knowing what's a good onion, or how to navigate a magickal library.

That's what I tell the players, but I'm actually lying.
The real reason is that players are shit writers and I don't want to read their awful bad-fanfiction-level backstories.

Cornucopia is an enchantment meant for ammunition, but you could probably get something by enchanting an object with both Create Water and Water to Wine, plus something to power the Create Water enchantment. >balance
balance is only important in video games because a video game developer is not there for the actual game and has to prepare things in advance so it's balanced. In a TTRPG the GM can balance as they go and most of the time without anyone being aware of it.

In a video game a weapon might need a nerf so that it isn't too overpowered late game, but for people who already completed the late game it's too late. In a TTRPG the GM can simply pull out a more powerful encounter, drop some things that buff the other players to be on the level of the overpowered one, or have them face off against enemies that don't make the weapon's gimmick too overpowered or whatever. Or, for a less subtle GM catching the problem when it appears, they can just say "that's going to be broken so we're going to have to change it/take it out, sorry".
